iati-activity.title: Nabari Community Empowerment Project
iati-activity.description: Subtitle: Waterpumps, rainwater harvesting and latrines in Nabari and Silinga.

Summary: Cordaid works together with the Rotary Club Oosterbeek Kabeljauw to support the local partner organization Pumping is Life Ghana. The project aims to provide 3 rope pump water supply systems, 7 rainwater harvesting systems, 10 household latrines and 2 schoolgardens in Nabari community. The maintenance will be done by the local people of the community, who will be trained for this.

Goal Overview: To provide the community with access to clean water and latrines, as well as the structures to store water during the rain period. Further, to realise 2 schoolgardens to provide food for the schoolchildren and by this improve their health status.

Target Groups: The water facilities will benefit 50 families, the sanitation and hygiene facilities 55 families, and the schoolgardens 750 students. In total the project will reach 4745 inhabitants of Nabari and Silinga community.

Background: This project is designed in resonse to a community needs assessment carried out in May 2013. According to this assessment, the main priorities in the community are water, sanitation and hygiene and school gardens.

Project Plan: The project will be delivered in three forms:
- Potable water supply. This consists of both drilling and construction of 7 rain water harvesting systems and the installation of 3 rope pumps;
- Sanitation and hygiene education. This consists of the construction of 10 household latrines. Also, hygiene training is given, and 30 hands washing facilities are constructed.
- School garden. The project will establish 2 school gardens to produce food to complement the school feeding programme. The garden will consist of a water supply system, a fence, tools and planting materials. Labour for the garden will be provided by the parents and by the students.

Sustainability: The maintenance of the project will be done mainly by the local people of the community themselves. The people who will be assigned to look after the pump, well, tank and latrines will be trained. Furthermore, the local partner organization Pumping is Life will keep in contact with the community, so in case additional support or maintenance is needed it will be organized.
Initial Situation: Cordaid had supported the Rotary Club Oosterbeek Kabeljauw earlier in the period 2002 to 2005 with different projects in Swaziland.

iati-activity.title: Exchange knowledge on health insurance
iati-activity.description: Subtitle: Promote successful initiatives

Summary: The African Health Insurance Knowledge Alliance shares the experience of African countries with health insurance schemes. This can be of great value to other countries working with or developing health insurance schemes. Knowledge and skills which are required to design and run efficient, administrative processes are seldom taught at universities or business schools.

Goal Overview: The objective of this initiative is to build local capacities in order to ensure efficient and transparent health insurance systems in Africa. Local capacity building, e.g. on health insurance administration and management, has been recognised as an important factor for developing sustainable health insurance schemes and systems. Technology (mobile telephony), medical practice and pharmacy, and regulations.

Target Groups: Direct target group: the 25 participants from both Ghanaian and Ugandan health sector involved in setting up and improving their National Health Insurance Systems.
Indirect target group: the populations of both Uganda (21 million) and Ghana ( 23 million) who will in the long run be the beneficiaries of their National Health Insurance Systems.

Background: Sub-Saharan Africa has about 25% of the global disease burden yet attracts only 1% of the global health investment. Donor support has not contributed to increased capacity of the public health care sector to address the health needs of poor people. In an effort to mobilize additional resources for an under-funded health sector, user fees were introduced. Up to 60% of health expenditures in Sub-Saharan Africa are out-of pocket expenses by poor people.
Considering the massive challenges facing Africa’s healthcare systems, several major reforms will be needed to ensure their viability in the long term such as giving local communities more control over decision-making and healthcare resources; addressing human resource for health; reducing reliance on international aid and fostering the development of more dependable local systems; and extending health insurance coverage to the poorest.

Project Plan: The feasibility study will firstly determine demand and competition. It will entail reported conclusions and recommendations on:
1. Review and report on existing health insurance knowledge centres or departments in the region 2. Review and report on existing Feasibility Studies and Data 3. Partnership Identification and planning 4. Location – site selection 5. Optimum size (both for the centre(s), and for the activities) 6. Conceptual design alternatives 7. Capital and operating costs 8. Financial “Pro Forma” analysis 9. Implementation Plan 10. Identify potential funding sources

Sustainability: The project in itself (the meeting of health experts from Ghana and Uganda) will not be sustainable, but the aim of meeting is to work towards sustainable Health Insurance Systems in both countries.
Initial Situation: This is a separate activity that is not in itself a follow-up of earlier activities in the past years.

iati-activity.title: Agricultural finance product development
iati-activity.description: Subtitle: Increasing Access to Agricultural Finance for Farming Households

Summary: Most farming households in Africa lack access to appropriate financial services. Cordaid and MicroSave, a Kenyan organization specialized in product development, have obtained funding from the EU to support 6 to 10 Microfinance Institutions to develop financial products for farmers, to link these farmers to agricultural service providers and to elaborate appropriate risk mitigating measures.

Goal Overview: The objective of the project is to increase access to appropriate agricultural finance for farming households. 6-10 Participating MFIs will have developed or refined agricultural microfinance products and by the end of 2014 14.000 new MFI clients will have accessed an agricultural loan product. Furthermore the MFIs will have developed appropriate risk mitigating measures associated with agricultural financing. Half of the MFIs will have succesfully linked their clients to agricultural service providers. 75% of the agricultural clients will have received financial education.

Target Groups: The project works with 6 to 10 Microfinance Institutions but the indirect target groups are farming households: low income entrepreneurial farmers (men and women) who are or will become clients from the MFIs.

Background: The majority of the population in Uganda, Kenya, Ethiopia and Ghana lives in rural areas and is dependent on agriculture. Farmers in these countries are among the poorest of the world, facing problems of deteriorating soils, climate change effects, lack of agricultural extension services, appropriate inputs, access to markets and financial services. Food security is a permanent concern. The microfinance sector is developing well. However, despite the fact that financial services providers reach out more and more to rural areas, they still are hesitant to provide agricultural finance because of high costs and risks involved and a lack of knowledge and experience.

Project Plan: Cordaid implements the project together with MicroSave. MicroSave was established in Africa in 1998 and promotes the development of a market-led and more client-responsive approach to delivering financial services among microfinance institutions (MFIs). MicroSave has extensive experience in product development. MicroSave and Cordaid have obtained funding from the EU/ACP microfinance Programme. The project runs from October 2012 to December 2014.
Main activities include: 1. Implementation of a 10-step product development process with MFIs (from market analysis to roll-out and evaluation). 2. Linking MFIs and clients to producer organizations, agricultural extension services providers and/or value chain support. 3. Development of financial education curriculum in one MFI and training of trainers of partner MFI. 4. Support to MFIs in identification of risk-mitigating measures, with respect to their agricultural microfinance portfolio.
The project is implemented in Kenya, Uganda, Ethiopia and Ghana.

Sustainability: The participating MFIs will receive training and advice in product development, risk mitigation and linking clients to agricultural service providers. After the end of the project, they are expected to have the capacity to continue and repeat these activities without external support.

Initial Situation: The project has started in October 2012. 9 of the 11 organizations that submitted a concept note have been selected to submit a full proposal. The project team will visit the 9 MFIs in March 2013 to make the final selection.

iati-activity.title: ACDEP: ICT in Healthcare Delivery
iati-activity.description:
Background: The NGO Association of Church-based Development (ACDEP) is based in Northern Ghana, and most of their partner health institutions are located in deprived rural areas in this part of the country. The geographical isolation, widespread poverty and structural social-cultural problems negatively impact on the health of a significant proportion of the population. Maternal and child mortality rates are significantly higher compared to the south of Ghana.
Health facilities in Norther Ghana insufficiently make us of modern Information Communication Technologies (ICT) to promote health care delivery services in the communities that they operate in. Apart from financial reasons, this is due to low ICT capacity or lack of appreciation for the value of ICT in health. Moreover, the existing ICT centers do not respond in time nor in content to the immediate information and communication needs of health workers and communities.

Project Plan: The ICT capacity of the health institutions will be built and strengthened. Staff will be trained in ICT skills and encouraged to actively use the system to access health information (including making requests to the ACDEP Secretariat). Appropriate technologies will be deployed at the ACDEP Secretariat to manage this exchange, while key staff at the health institutions will be trained to manage and facilitate the process at institutional level.
Over 1.500 community health volunteers, peer educators, adolescent clubs, traditional medical practitioners and traditional birth attendants within the project’s operational areas will be sensitized to using these institutional level community health information centers for all their health information needs. This includes community engagement with duty bearers, who renege on their responsibilities to provide basic healthcare delivery services to the communities.
In short, training and capacity building will be a strong component of this project as the current level of confidence, appreciation, and interactive use of ICT for health development among the stakeholders is low.

Sustainability: The training and capacity building of the staff of the health units is the main component of this project as this will be a continuous and required skill of the staff. The current level of confidence, appreciation and interactive use of ICT for health development among the stakeholders will be significantly increased. After the initial procurement of ICT material and training of staff, the quality of the health services will be increased. Knowledge transfer is also aimed at Traditional Medical Practitioners and Traditional Birth Attendants for a greater outreach to the population.

Initial Situation: Since 1996 Cordaid supports ACDEP in different programs as capacity building, health activities, ICT and economic development. Because of the gained capacity, ACDEP was able to take over programs of international NGOs in the region.
Subtitle: Improving efficiency in communication and healthcare in Northern Ghana

Summary: The project is being implemented to address the poor communication and information flow among health workers and key departments within the health facilities. We will facilitate two-way feedback from both community health workers and community members, which is essential to provide useful information for future decisions and community health planning.

Goal Overview: With this project we aim to integrate appropriate and sustainable use of ICT into the operational activities of 10 health centers to improve the quality of health services for the population in northern Ghana by the end of 2014.

Target Groups: The direct target group consists of: - staff ACDEP member institutions (50) - partner health institutions (10) - community health volunteers (60)
The final beneficiaries are: - the population in the target area of the health institutions (173.000)
